Adverbs and AdvP Adverbs express four basic types of information:
time,
location,
manner, and
reason or purpose.
Indefinite adverbs will also be presented here and interrogative adverbs will be covered in section
Questions - Interrogative phrases. These types have different characteristics as to which positions they may occupy and how they may be modified, so they need to be distinguished from each other by a feature. We will deal with each in turn.
Temporal adverbs express time and include the English words: already, then, soon, now, later, and always.
These need to be distinguished from other types of words or phrases that can also express the time in a sentence, such as:
nominal phrases yesterday, last night, next year, tomorrow, a long time ago,
prepositional phrases for a long time, in a little while, at 10 o’clock, and
adverbial clauses while you are working, when Sue arrived.
You will be asked about the simple nouns that express time below. Temporal prepositional or postpositional phrases will be covered in
Adpostpositional Phrases and adverbial clauses will be covered in
Adverbial Clauses.

Now consider the simple nouns that express time, such as night, year, day, yesterday, tomorrow, time, morning and hour. Proper names for the days of the week and months of the year are also temporal nouns.
Key examples of how your languages expresses these concepts here:
In the lexicon, add the feature temporal to each of the nouns that relate to time. These nouns can normally be modified by most of the modifiers other nouns can, such as articles, demonstratives and quantifiers, but especially including words like early and late, as in the early morning. Note that more than one temporal noun can also occur together in a compound, as in late yesterday morning.

We will assume that the words early and late act as adjectives when they occur in a nominal phrase and as prepositions or postpositions when they take either a nominal phrase or a PP as their complement. Therefore, in the lexicon, you will likely need to have two entries for these words, one with the category Adj and one with the category P and the feature temporal (or you can use the features makeP temporal instead).
There are also two types of temporal adverbial indefinites: those built from a quantifier and a general temporal noun, such as everytime and sometime, and those built from an word and an indefinite word, such as whenever.
First, consider the temporal adverbial indefinites that include a quantifier, such as ‘everytime’, ‘anytime’ and ‘sometime’. How does your language express these temporal adverbial indefinites?
